The Landlord
Students have always complained about
the Housing Office—specifically about the
problems they've had with apartment
maintanence.
Well, students now have an opportunity
to complain. The Student Council Housing
Committee has distributed questionnaires
regarding the situation, which means it's up
to you to complain in writing.
Otherwise, the committee won't be able
to present anything substantial to the administration. And everyone knows how the
administration needs to see proof of wrongdoing before they even consider making any
plans for improvements.
If the committee finds any faults with the
maintenance of University-owned off-

campus housing, then it's a disgrace that the
landlord is being negligent. The typical
landlord will either make repairs or the te-

nant can simply refuse to pay his rent. Unfortunately, this can't be done with this
landlord. Hopkins tenants must pay one
lump sum at the beginning of each semester
as President Maureen Freed pointed out at
Wednesday's council meeting.
If the committee does discover problems
and if such problems are not rectified, then
students have two options. They may demand that the rent payment procedure be
changed, or pay the one lump sum at the end
of the semester—that is, if they don't encounter any substantial maintenance
problems.

Save the Seals
To The Editor:
During the Student Council
meeting of March 7, we were
struck by the comment "you
might as well make the SAC
seals the senior class awards."
Although this comment was
made out of exasperation, we
feel that the proposal should be
seriously considered. We agree
with the many criticisms of the
process by which the seals are
awarded and feel that the best
way to truly recognize accomplishment is to leave the
decision to the senior class.
We feel the best way to proceed is to require all students
who wish to be considered to
submit to the senior class officers a standard application
which includes an essay describing the student's activities. To
avoid a massive influx of candidates, specific prerequisites
should be included; one possible example is at least two years
of active participation in a student group or a Student Council committee. In addition, we
feel that activity in a fraternity

or sorority should be considered on equal footing with
activity in a studetn group. By
using this process, each student
has the opportunity to present
his credentials and thus
eliminate the possibility of being overlooked.
We also agree with the contention that the large number of
SAC seals reduces the
significance of the award. To
rectify the situation, one of two
options should be considered:
limiting once again the number
of seals to 25, or, as Maureen
suggested, instituting a twotiered system where a very small
number of special awards will
be given to those with exceptional contributions to student
life and a larger number of seals
will be given to those with
noteworthy contributions.
In short, we feel the current
system of awarding SAC seals
is inadequate and misrepresentative. A new process should be
instituted to make these awards
more meaningful.

The name Johns Hopkins
evokes images of the pursuit of
academic excellence; however,
in the study of women in
various disciplines, the University has faltered. "Women in
History, Culture and Society"

currently being conducted on

one needs to look at traditional

challenges are being made that

the progression of history.

Western historians have
depicted history as a series of
political events marked by the
presence of great men. While
these catalysts change political
structures, they often do not
significantly alter the position
of women. Thus, women have
by and large been ignored in
western history.
Revision in the areas of anpsychology,
thropology,
political science, sociology and
economics are shedding new
light on once central assumptions in these fields. There is an
immediate need to make
Hopkins curriculum responsive
to this research. Endowed with
a small grant from the Kenan
Fund for the improvement of
undergraduate education,
Hartsock, Martin and Begus
created a course to meet this
need and in doing so, set an example of innovation and
academic excellence.

The nature of the material
covered in "Women in History,
Society"
and
Culture
necessitates that it be taught as
an interdisciplinary course.
Scholarly research on women
does not occur in isolated
pockets, but transcends the
interdisciplines.

disciplinary aspect enhances the
course. Exposure to scholars,
research and students from different, but related, fields
broadens one's scope of
knowledge.

unique format of this course on
women. The course is divided
into two time periods. Each
week, a guest speaker from the
discipline being studied lectures
and answers questions during a
two-hour class. The speakers,
holding positions on the

"Unfaithfully Yours," starring

serious.
Conductor Claude Eastman

half his age, Daniella (Kinski).
His best friend, Norman
(Brooks), hires a private eye to
follow her while Eastman is in
London for a week. The P.I.'s
report is disturbing—a man has
been seen leaving the Eastman
apartment at 1:30 a.m.
Eastman doesn't want to
believe that his wife has been
untrue to him. "Maybe
something broke, and he was a
repairman," he says.
The detective disagrees.
"The only things that get
broken in the middle of the
night are the hearts of older
men like us," he says, and
Eastman accepts the sorry
judgment.
Eastman's prime suspect is
his young protege, violinist
Max Stein (Assante), who is a
notorious runabout with married women. Eastman confirms
his suspicions in scenes packed

with dramatic irony—the audience knows Daniella is innocent, but everything points to
her dalliance with Max.

straightman, and he contributes

more than a little cruel, in light
of the giggly tone of everything
that went on before. There's
even blood on the knife after
Eastman kills Daniella.

realism stops the film dead. The
mishaps involved in making his

nasty dream come true take up
the rest of the film, and some
of them are superbly crafted
comic bits. The ending is pretty unsatisfying, however.
"Unfaithfully Yours" gives
us the Dudley Moore everybody
loved in "Arthur" and "10."
Here he once again runs around
in the grip of an irresistible
compulsion.

Moore a boost. Albert Brooks

Life at Peabody is not Unlike Homewood

Dania Telizyn and Ruth Rose employ "Hut-like" enthusiasm to their art.

by Eric Fink
Our story begins in antebellum Baltimore, a city
thriving in commerce but nearly devoid of culture. In
1857, a well known Baltimore merchant, George
Peabody, desiring to hasten the city's cultural development, proposed the establishment of an educational
institution consisting of a Library, Art Gallery,
Academy of Music, and Lecture Series. The first
building, housing the Conservatory, was completed in
1861, but dedication was delayed another five years
because of the Civil War. The Conservatory commenced formal instruction in 1868, with 148 students.
Over the next century, Peabody continued to grow
in both size and prestige, adding significantly to the
cultural life of Baltimore. Many great works of music
received their area premieres at Peabody, and the Institute played a major role in the establishment of the
Baltimore Symphony Orchestra. Today, there remain
close ties between the two, with over one-third of the
of Orchestra's members being Peabody faculty.
In 1977, financial considerations resulted in the formal affiliation of the Peabody Institute with the Johns
Hopkins University. The formal relationship of the

Bill Meeker

A Pseudo-Greek statue adorning the inside of Peabody.

two schools has a strong historical precedent. Not only
have Hopkins and Peabody often cooperated in
academic ventures for many years, but their respective founders, George Peabody and Johns Hopkins,
were close friends. Peabody once referred to Hopkins
as "the only man more thoroughly anxious to make
money than myself." Much of Hopkins' inspiration
in endowing the school and hospital which bear his
name is said to have come from Peabody.
Today, the Peabody Conservatory enrolls about 500
students pursuing undergraduate, graduate, and
special degrees in various musical fields. They have
come to Peabody from all over the United States and
several foreign countries, drawn by Peabody's tremendous reputation for excellence in musical education.
Peabody graduates are represented among the ranks
of the finest orchestras and opera companies in the

Larry Volz

country. The school's commitment to providing a level
of culture to the city of Baltimore remains unabated,
with the Conservatory acting, in the words of one student, as a "direct feeder into the Baltimore Opera
Company and Symphony Orchestra."
At first glance, Peabody would seem to represent
a radically different side of the Johns Hopkins family. But talk to a Peabody student, and you will soon
find that the Conservatory and Homewood share
much more than just a formal University affiliation.
Peabody students express many of the same concerns
about their school and student life that are so often
heard here at Homewood.
Like other Hopkins institutions, Peabody has a well
deserved reputation for academic pressure that seems
almost a component part of the high level of academic
excellence at the school. Just as Hopkins students must
squeeze extra hours out of each day to complete an
Orgo lab or History paper, so do Peabody students
find their time far too insufficient for the amount of
practice, performance, and ensemble work they are expected to complete. Students mentioned two main problems stemming from this pressure which will be all
too familiar to the Homewood undergraduate.
Because of the limited number of top places in orchestras, opera companies, and such, there often
develops extreme competition between students. The
Hopkins pre-med may be surprised to learn that
throats exist among music students. But while there
is no mutilation of lab results, there is a problem of
some students hogging precious practice rooms. Mary
Carole Brown, now a senior Natural Sciences major,
transferred to Hopkins after two years as a trumpet
major at Peabody. Brown says that while she was at
the Conservatory, she often saw students "cheer"
when one of their fellows made a mistake in a difficult
passage. The general attitude, as Brown saw it, was
that the other students represented too great a tnreat
to risk helping someone improve his skills.
Most at Peabody, however, do not feel that the
situation is so extreme. "Our careers as musicians will
be oriented towards a group function," says Marci
Plait, a graduate student in voice. She finds that most
students are willing to work together, and notes that
ensemble requirements make some group effort
unavoidable.
Also stemming from the severe time demands is the
lack of a strong student social life pointed to any
Peabody students. Their complaints sound iike an echo
of the continual griping of Homewoodians about the
non-existant social life at Hopkins. Mark Paris, the
President of Peabody's Student Council, points out
that the entire budget for student activities at the Conservatory is $5000, or about $10 per student. Compare
that to the SAC budget at Hopkins and you can begin
to imagine the seriousness of the problem.
The quality of teaching and the attitude of Professors towards students is yet another theme which
is common to both divisions. According to Tom Arnold, a voice student, the Conservatory suffers from
"the misconception that a good performer is necessarily a good teacher." Paris agrees, saying that it is
"risky" to have musicians who are adept at the skill
of playing an instrument teaching courses not concerned with technical proficiency. While the students agree
that the Peabody faculty abounds in excellent musicians, they feel that it includes too few excellent
teachers.

Part of the blame, says Plait, is attributable to the
lack of any system of evaluation by students of
teachers. This problem has been addressed by the Student Council, which recently initiated course evaluations similar to those used by the Course Guide. So
far, the evaluations have met with positive response
from students and teachers alike. Another Council
proposal, an award to be given at graduation to a
teacher selected by the students, is being considered
by the Peabody administration.
Another difficulty that students often experience
regarding professors is their lack of availability for advising. "Faculty participation with students," says
Paris, "is greatest during practice and ensemble sessions." Outside of the class or practice room, students
feel, there is too little formal or informal interaction
between students and faculty. Many faculty members
are also professional musicians, and thus have little
time to devote to their students.
The very existence of the Student Council at
Peabody is tribute to the growing interest in improving student life at the Conservatory. When Mark Paris
arrived at Peabody after receiving an undergraduate

degree in Politics from Muhlenberg, there was no Student Council and few student organizations of any
kind. "Three years ago," he says, "this place was a

weekly Peabody Rag which lets members of the
Peabody community know what is going on. They
have also instituted a Grievance Board, with Tom Arnold as chairman, to identify and attempt to resolve
student complaints. The Board receives complaints in
writing and then communicates them to the appropriate administration or faculty person. In the first

One interesting suggestion voiced by the students is

idea, expressing a desire to "dig this whole block up

"I'd like to see Peabody be the music students of

fields around it. "You have to be able to think before

And the music students would not be the only ones
who could profit from such ties. Who knows, that guy
next to you in Orgo lab may be the next Pablo Casals
just waiting to be uncovered.

The way it looks now, this
March could be the last bow for
the National Invitation Tournament, the oldest national
basketball tournament in the
nation. With the NCAA going
to 64 teams next year, it would
seem to be the death knell for
that basketball mecca called
Madison Square Garden.
They say the beat must go on,
but for me there's only sadness
to see the white flag go up, see
the Goliaths finally kill David,
to watch the lights go out and
the NIT become a part of the
past, a piece of nostalgia, like
minor league baseball, semi-pro
football, the nickel candy bar,
and toy soldiers made out of
lead.
Ever since the NIT got its
slap on the bottom in 1938, a
year before the NCAA saw the
light, fans have thrilled to many
great moments. Like back in
1945 when Ernie Calverly made
his shot from half-court for the
University of Rhode Island, to
put the game against Bowling
Green into overtime. Bowling
Green went on to win that one,
but then DePaul and coach Ray
Meyer grabbed the brass ring
by beating the Falcons, behind
George Mikan, the first of the
great big men.
Another memorable NIT
would have to be 1950, when
City College of New York
became the only team in college
history to win both the NIT and
the NCAA in the same year.
Back in those days, you could
enter both, and Bradley University was the Beavers' victim in
the title game both times.
Over the years, the NIT has
been a showcase for great
players, like Tommy Heinsohn,
Kevin
Lenny
Wilkins,
Loughery, John Shumate, Gary
Brokaw and who can ever
forget Sihugo Green, who
scored 33 points in Duquesne's
1955 title victory!
Personally, I'll never forget
when Southern Illinois held
George (Brute Force) Thompson, Marquette's all-time
leading scorer, to 12 points and
Walt Frazier scored 21 to beat
us in the 1967 title game. And,
of course, the 1970 NIT, which
we won, after I'd told the
NCAA to take a hike when they
sent us out of our mideast
regional to the midwest.
During my playing days at
St. John's, in the early 1950's,
we went to the NIT three times
under Frank McGuire. Back
then, the garden was the
Zenith, Miller time, the
ultimate stage for all coaches
and ballplayers to appear on.
That's the old garden I'm talking about, on 49th St. and 8th
Ave. It was the first place college basketball became big
business.

There are, in my opinion,
three ways the NIT might still
survive. One way they might exist is by taking eight of the 32
first-round losers from the
NCAA tourney each year, and
stage a shoot-out at the garden.
There's always a number of
wild upsets in the first round,
which could end up being a
bonanza rather than a Dunkirk
for the NIT.
The only drawback is, they'd
have to get permission from
Shawnee Mission to do that,
and I'd bet the farm, Shawnee
might be a little slow on the
draw.
The NIT could also consider
inviting four European teams
against four predominantly
eastern teams to get the regional
flavor that would attract the
student bodies and alumni.
Again, those four might be
schools that didn't make the
NCAA.
Start of the season, a preseason shoot-out on Thanksgiving weekend, bringing in eight
powers from
dynamite
throughout the country, with a
limited amount of flavor for
the Big East television corridor
from Boston to Washington,
D.C.
By doing that, it would allow

continuity, and would keep
alive the NIT tradition that has
truly been one of the centerpieces of collegiate basketball
for more than 40 years.
Unless one of those three options become reality, it's taps city for the NIT. The first option
won't happen because it would
take away something from the
NCAA Tourney, and since
they're in competition dollarwise and publicity-wise, it's
doubtful the NCAA would be
that charitable. Look for
Scrooge McDuck to open his
value first.
The problem with the second
option is that it would need the
clearing of various basketball
associations to let the Europeans play, because you'd need
some type of sanction. It'd
have to be cleared through the
World Federation, through the
NCAA, the state department
and maybe even Ronnie the
Hotline. Too much red tape.
With the third idea, the problem is, most coaches want to
start their season with cupcakes, sure wins, and don't
want to risk a slip in the rankings or a team letdown by playing, and possibly losing to
heavyweights right out of the
gate.
Believe me, coaches spend
months trying to find the
weakest teams they can play.
They look for teams that wear
snowshoes when they play, and
have at least three guys that still
use the two-hand dribble.
So, barring a parting of the
Red Sea, it looks like March 26
and 28 will be the last two
garden parties for the NIT. The
tide, it seems, has gone out, and
there's no more sand in the
hourglass.

Save the Seals
To The Editor:
During the Student Council
meeting of March 7, we were
struck by the comment "you
might as well make the SAC
seals the senior class awards."
Although this comment was
made out of exasperation, we
feel that the proposal should be
seriously considered. We agree
with the many criticisms of the
process by which the seals are
awarded and feel that the best
way to truly recognize accomplishment is to leave the
decision to the senior class.
We feel the best way to proceed is to require all students
who wish to be considered to
submit to the senior class officers a standard application
which includes an essay describing the student's activities. To
avoid a massive influx of candidates, specific prerequisites
should be included; one possible example is at least two years
of active participation in a student group or a Student Council committee. In addition, we
feel that activity in a fraternity

or sorority should be considered on equal footing with
activity in a studetn group. By
using this process, each student
has the opportunity to present
his credentials and thus
eliminate the possibility of being overlooked.
We also agree with the contention that the large number of
SAC seals reduces the
significance of the award. To
rectify the situation, one of two
options should be considered:
limiting once again the number
of seals to 25, or, as Maureen
suggested, instituting a twotiered system where a very small
number of special awards will
be given to those with exceptional contributions to student
life and a larger number of seals
will be given to those with
noteworthy contributions.
In short, we feel the current
system of awarding SAC seals
is inadequate and misrepresentative. A new process should be
instituted to make these awards
more meaningful.

The name Johns Hopkins
evokes images of the pursuit of
academic excellence; however,
in the study of women in

structures, they often do not
significantly alter the position
of women. Thus, women have
by and large been ignored in
western history.

thropology,
political science, sociology and
economics are shedding new
light on once central assumptions in these fields. There is an
immediate need to make
Hopkins curriculum responsive
to this research. Endowed with
a small grant from the Kenan
Fund for the improvement of
undergraduate education,
Hartsock, Martin and Begus
created a course to meet this
need and in doing so, set an example of innovation and
academic excellence.

The nature of the material
covered in "Women in History,
Society"
and
Culture

an interdisciplinary course.
Scholarly research on women
does not occur in isolated
pockets, but transcends the
interdisciplines.

disciplinary aspect enhances the
course. Exposure to scholars,
research and students from different, but related, fields
broadens one's scope of
knowledge.

unique format of this course on
women. The course is divided
into two time periods. Each
week, a guest speaker from the
discipline being studied lectures
and answers questions during a
two-hour class. The speakers,

Hopkins.

"Unfaithfully Yours," starring

with some powerful emotions

serious.
Conductor Claude Eastman
(Moore)is married to a woman
half his age, Daniella (Kinski).
His best friend, Norman
(Brooks), hires a private eye to
follow her while Eastman is in
London for a week. The P.I.'s
report is disturbing—a man has
been seen leaving the Eastman
apartment at 1:30 a.m.
Eastman doesn't want to
believe that his wife has been
untrue to him. "Maybe
something broke, and he was a
repairman," he says.
The detective disagrees.
"The only things that get
broken in the middle of the
night are the hearts of older
men like us," he says, and
Eastman accepts the sorry
judgment.
Eastman's prime suspect is
his young protege, violinist
Max Stein (Assante), who is a
notorious runabout with married women. Eastman confirms
his suspicions in scenes packed

with dramatic irony—the audience knows Daniella is innocent, but everything points to
her dalliance with Max.
Assante is a remarkably subtle
straightman, and he contributes
a nice understatement to offset
Moore's slapstick frenzy.

characters are and that he plans

realistically lined out and is
more than a little cruel, in light
of the giggly tone of everything
that went on before. There's
even blood on the knife after
Eastman kills Daniella.

realism stops the film dead. The
mishaps involved in making his

nasty dream come true take up
the rest of the film, and some
of them are superbly crafted
comic bits. The ending is pretty unsatisfying, however.
"Unfaithfully Yours" gives
us the Dudley Moore everybody
loved in "Arthur" and "10."
Here he once again runs around
in the grip of an irresistible
compulsion.

Moore a boost. Albert Brooks

Life at Peabody is not Unlike Homewood

Dania Telizyn and Ruth Rose employ "Hut-like" enthusiasm to their art.

by Eric Fink
Our story begins in antebellum Baltimore, a city
thriving in commerce but nearly devoid of culture. In
1857, a well known Baltimore merchant, George
Peabody, desiring to hasten the city's cultural development, proposed the establishment of an educational
institution consisting of a Library, Art Gallery,
Academy of Music, and Lecture Series. The first
building, housing the Conservatory, was completed in
1861, but dedication was delayed another five years
because of the Civil War. The Conservatory commenced formal instruction in 1868, with 148 students.
Over the next century, Peabody continued to grow
in both size and prestige, adding significantly to the
cultural life of Baltimore. Many great works of music
received their area premieres at Peabody, and the Institute played a major role in the establishment of the
Baltimore Symphony Orchestra. Today, there remain
close ties between the two, with over one-third of the
of Orchestra's members being Peabody faculty.
In 1977, financial considerations resulted in the formal affiliation of the Peabody Institute with the Johns
Hopkins University. The formal relationship of the

Bill Meeker

A Pseudo-Greek statue adorning the inside of Peabody.

two schools has a strong historical precedent. Not only
have Hopkins and Peabody often cooperated in
academic ventures for many years, but their respective founders, George Peabody and Johns Hopkins,
were close friends. Peabody once referred to Hopkins
as "the only man more thoroughly anxious to make
money than myself." Much of Hopkins' inspiration
in endowing the school and hospital which bear his
name is said to have come from Peabody.
Today, the Peabody Conservatory enrolls about 500
students pursuing undergraduate, graduate, and
special degrees in various musical fields. They have
come to Peabody from all over the United States and
several foreign countries, drawn by Peabody's tremendous reputation for excellence in musical education.
Peabody graduates are represented among the ranks
of the finest orchestras and opera companies in the

Larry Volz

country. The school's commitment to providing a level
of culture to the city of Baltimore remains unabated,
with the Conservatory acting, in the words of one student, as a "direct feeder into the Baltimore Opera
Company and Symphony Orchestra."
At first glance, Peabody would seem to represent
a radically different side of the Johns Hopkins family. But talk to a Peabody student, and you will soon
find that the Conservatory and Homewood share
much more than just a formal University affiliation.
Peabody students express many of the same concerns
about their school and student life that are so often
heard here at Homewood.
Like other Hopkins institutions, Peabody has a well
deserved reputation for academic pressure that seems
almost a component part of the high level of academic
excellence at the school. Just as Hopkins students must
squeeze extra hours out of each day to complete an
Orgo lab or History paper, so do Peabody students
find their time far too insufficient for the amount of
practice, performance, and ensemble work they are expected to complete. Students mentioned two main problems stemming from this pressure which will be all
too familiar to the Homewood undergraduate.
Because of the limited number of top places in orchestras, opera companies, and such, there often
develops extreme competition between students. The
Hopkins pre-med may be surprised to learn that
throats exist among music students. But while there
is no mutilation of lab results, there is a problem of
some students hogging precious practice rooms. Mary
Carole Brown, now a senior Natural Sciences major,
transferred to Hopkins after two years as a trumpet
major at Peabody. Brown says that while she was at
the Conservatory, she often saw students "cheer"
when one of their fellows made a mistake in a difficult
passage. The general attitude, as Brown saw it, was
that the other students represented too great a tnreat
to risk helping someone improve his skills.
Most at Peabody, however, do not feel that the
situation is so extreme. "Our careers as musicians will
be oriented towards a group function," says Marci
Plait, a graduate student in voice. She finds that most
students are willing to work together, and notes that
ensemble requirements make some group effort
unavoidable.
Also stemming from the severe time demands is the
lack of a strong student social life pointed to any
Peabody students. Their complaints sound iike an echo
of the continual griping of Homewoodians about the
non-existant social life at Hopkins. Mark Paris, the
President of Peabody's Student Council, points out
that the entire budget for student activities at the Conservatory is $5000, or about $10 per student. Compare
that to the SAC budget at Hopkins and you can begin
to imagine the seriousness of the problem.
The quality of teaching and the attitude of Professors towards students is yet another theme which
is common to both divisions. According to Tom Arnold, a voice student, the Conservatory suffers from
"the misconception that a good performer is necessarily a good teacher." Paris agrees, saying that it is
"risky" to have musicians who are adept at the skill
of playing an instrument teaching courses not concerned with technical proficiency. While the students agree
that the Peabody faculty abounds in excellent musicians, they feel that it includes too few excellent
teachers.

Part of the blame, says Plait, is attributable to the
lack of any system of evaluation by students of
teachers. This problem has been addressed by the Student Council, which recently initiated course evaluations similar to those used by the Course Guide. So
far, the evaluations have met with positive response
from students and teachers alike. Another Council
proposal, an award to be given at graduation to a
teacher selected by the students, is being considered
by the Peabody administration.
Another difficulty that students often experience
regarding professors is their lack of availability for advising. "Faculty participation with students," says
Paris, "is greatest during practice and ensemble sessions." Outside of the class or practice room, students
feel, there is too little formal or informal interaction
between students and faculty. Many faculty members
are also professional musicians, and thus have little
time to devote to their students.
The very existence of the Student Council at
Peabody is tribute to the growing interest in improving student life at the Conservatory. When Mark Paris
arrived at Peabody after receiving an undergraduate

degree in Politics from Muhlenberg, there was no Student Council and few student organizations of any
kind. "Three years ago," he says, "this place was a

weekly Peabody Rag which lets members of the

have also instituted a Grievance Board, with Tom Arnold as chairman, to identify and attempt to resolve
student complaints. The Board receives complaints in

fields around it. "You have to be able to think before

And the music students would not be the only ones
who could profit from such ties. Who knows, that guy
next to you in Orgo lab may be the next Pablo Casals
just waiting to be uncovered.

The way it looks now, this
March could be the last bow for
the National Invitation Tournament, the oldest national
basketball tournament in the
nation. With the NCAA going
to 64 teams next year, it would
seem to be the death knell for
that basketball mecca called
Madison Square Garden.
They say the beat must go on,
but for me there's only sadness
to see the white flag go up, see
the Goliaths finally kill David,
to watch the lights go out and
the NIT become a part of the
past, a piece of nostalgia, like
minor league baseball, semi-pro
football, the nickel candy bar,
and toy soldiers made out of
lead.
Ever since the NIT got its
slap on the bottom in 1938, a
year before the NCAA saw the
light, fans have thrilled to many
great moments. Like back in
1945 when Ernie Calverly made
his shot from half-court for the
University of Rhode Island, to
put the game against Bowling
Green into overtime. Bowling
Green went on to win that one,
but then DePaul and coach Ray
Meyer grabbed the brass ring
by beating the Falcons, behind
George Mikan, the first of the
great big men.
Another memorable NIT
would have to be 1950, when
City College of New York
became the only team in college
history to win both the NIT and
the NCAA in the same year.
Back in those days, you could
enter both, and Bradley University was the Beavers' victim in
the title game both times.
Over the years, the NIT has
been a showcase for great
players, like Tommy Heinsohn,
Kevin
Lenny
Wilkins,
Loughery, John Shumate, Gary
Brokaw and who can ever
forget Sihugo Green, who
scored 33 points in Duquesne's
1955 title victory!
Personally, I'll never forget
when Southern Illinois held
George (Brute Force) Thompson, Marquette's all-time
leading scorer, to 12 points and
Walt Frazier scored 21 to beat
us in the 1967 title game. And,
of course, the 1970 NIT, which
we won, after I'd told the
NCAA to take a hike when they
sent us out of our mideast
regional to the midwest.
During my playing days at
St. John's, in the early 1950's,
we went to the NIT three times
under Frank McGuire. Back
then, the garden was the
Zenith, Miller time, the
ultimate stage for all coaches
and ballplayers to appear on.
That's the old garden I'm talking about, on 49th St. and 8th
Ave. It was the first place college basketball became big
business.

There are, in my opinion,
three ways the NIT might still
survive. One way they might exist is by taking eight of the 32
first-round losers from the
NCAA tourney each year, and
stage a shoot-out at the garden.
There's always a number of
wild upsets in the first round,
which could end up being a
bonanza rather than a Dunkirk
for the NIT.
The only drawback is, they'd
have to get permission from
Shawnee Mission to do that,
and I'd bet the farm, Shawnee
might be a little slow on the
draw.
The NIT could also consider
inviting four European teams
against four predominantly
eastern teams to get the regional
flavor that would attract the
student bodies and alumni.
Again, those four might be
schools that didn't make the
NCAA.
Start of the season, a preseason shoot-out on Thanksgiving weekend, bringing in eight
powers from
dynamite
throughout the country, with a
limited amount of flavor for
the Big East television corridor
from Boston to Washington,
D.C.
By doing that, it would allow

continuity, and would keep
alive the NIT tradition that has
truly been one of the centerpieces of collegiate basketball
for more than 40 years.
Unless one of those three options become reality, it's taps city for the NIT. The first option
won't happen because it would
take away something from the
NCAA Tourney, and since
they're in competition dollarwise and publicity-wise, it's
doubtful the NCAA would be
that charitable. Look for
Scrooge McDuck to open his
value first.
The problem with the second
option is that it would need the
clearing of various basketball
associations to let the Europeans play, because you'd need
some type of sanction. It'd
have to be cleared through the
World Federation, through the
NCAA, the state department
and maybe even Ronnie the
Hotline. Too much red tape.
With the third idea, the problem is, most coaches want to
start their season with cupcakes, sure wins, and don't
want to risk a slip in the rankings or a team letdown by playing, and possibly losing to
heavyweights right out of the
gate.
Believe me, coaches spend
months trying to find the
weakest teams they can play.
They look for teams that wear
snowshoes when they play, and
have at least three guys that still
use the two-hand dribble.
So, barring a parting of the
Red Sea, it looks like March 26
and 28 will be the last two
garden parties for the NIT. The
tide, it seems, has gone out, and
there's no more sand in the
hourglass.

40-49,(5)50 plus, and divisions

finishing at 32:45, and Julie

Maryland Marathon. Defending
Andy
champion,

Hopkins participants. Julie
Smiddy, 27, is a Hopkins grad,
Vivek Samnotra placed second
in the 19 and under category at

group. Both the men and
women's junior divisions were
won by Hopkins people:
George Raiser at 36:22 and
Ceci King, 44:27.
Hopkins grad and present
Tutorial Director, Tracy Stambaugh, said Stewart staged a
very professional race. The runners were provided with split
times at various intervals—at
one, two, four, and six miles.
"It is important for distance
runners to maintain consistent
endurance," she said.
The Tutorial Project depends
on this race and other fundraisers for one-half of the program's annual budget. Hopkins
supports the other half of the
25 year old project's expenses.
The tutoring program consists of

of 100 volunteers, many

name, "Pablo Fargas," Stambaugh said, "You might think

marathoner or an Italian
baseball player. Not at all. In
1980 the Chaplain's Office
wanted to give the race a title.

name was picked from a hat
full of other tutorial students'
names."
Stanbaugh said his full name
is Pablo Vizcarronda Fargas.

said.

remembers the constant anxiety over funding. As a member

wanted to sponsor a benefit
race on July 4, 1980. Now the

fundraiser.

of 30 athletes, generally in their
middle to late 20s. "Running is
a lonely sport, and we enjoy
competing with others,"
Stewart said.

wind slowed the runners down.

expects to net $400.

black knit caps for each participant, donated by Sunny

received separate plaques.

Refreshments, orange juice,

Will he do it again next year?

said, "but I want to see some
improvements—better outside
sponsorship, more profitability, and additional premiums. A
big complaint was for an improved course. Racers don't
like to repeat on a run,"
Stewart said. "And we are professional runners. We want to
provide challenge."
"One thing for certain," he
concluded."We had quality of
competition and quantity of
participants."
